summary: The Staff Payroll Records consist of payroll authorizations, certification reports, and related memoranda documenting the compensation and employment of individuals working for the U.S. House of Representatives Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA) primarily from 1976 to 1979. These records detail employee names, positions, annual salaries, gross pay, and sometimes social security numbers (often redacted). The Assassination Records Review Board (ARRB) frequently postponed the release of Social Security numbers to protect personal privacy. These documents provide insights into the staffing, financial operations, and administrative processes of the HSCA, including salary adjustments, leave records, and certifications regarding familial relationships with members of Congress. Some records also pertain to compensation within the CIA and individuals connected to JMWAVE.
key_connections: U.S. House of Representatives Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA)

significance: High. The Staff Payroll Records are significant due to their direct connection to the HSCA's operations and staffing. The large number of documents (168) indicates the extensive record-keeping related to personnel and compensation. The records offer insights into the financial administration, staffing structure, and personnel management of the committee investigating the JFK assassination, making them valuable for understanding the committee's inner workings and resource allocation.
